steps.title: Understand the problem setup
steps.content: We have a solid with base bounded by the curve y = √((1-2x)cos x) for 3π/4 ≤ x ≤ 5π/4, the x-axis, and vertical lines x = 3π/4 and x = 5π/4. Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are squares with side length equal to y.

steps.title: Verify the function is real in the given interval
steps.content: For y = √((1-2x)cos x) to be real, we need (1-2x)cos x ≥ 0. In the interval [3π/4, 5π/4], cos x ≤ 0 (negative in second and third quadrants). Also, 1-2x < 0 since x > 1/2. Therefore (1-2x)cos x = (negative)(negative) = positive ≥ 0. The function is valid.

steps.title: Set up the volume integral
steps.content: For a solid with square cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis, the area of each cross-section is A(x) = y² = (1-2x)cos x. The volume is V = ∫[3π/4 to 5π/4] (1-2x)cos x dx.

steps.title: Split the integral
steps.content: V = ∫[3π/4 to 5π/4] cos x dx - 2∫[3π/4 to 5π/4] x·cos x dx. Let I₁ = ∫[3π/4 to 5π/4] cos x dx and I₂ = ∫[3π/4 to 5π/4] x·cos x dx.

steps.title: Evaluate I₂ using integration by parts
Combine results to find the volume
steps.content: V = I₁ - 2I₂ = -√2 - 2(-π√2) = -√2 + 2π√2 = 2√2π - √2. This matches option ③.

Claude Opus 4.5.feedback: All three attempts arrived at the same answer using the same correct methodology. The setup, integration by parts, and final calculation were all performed correctly. The volume is 2√2π - √2, which corresponds to option ③.

steps.title: Set up volume integral
steps.content: With square cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis, each slice at x has area equal to the square of the base segment length √((1−2x)cos x). Therefore A(x) = (1−2x)cos x and V = ∫_{3π/4}^{5π/4} (1−2x)cos x dx.

steps.title: Find antiderivative
steps.content: Compute ∫(1−2x)cos x dx = ∫cos x dx − 2∫x cos x dx = sin x − 2(x sin x + cos x) = (1−2x)sin x − 2 cos x.

steps.title: Evaluate definite integral
steps.content: At x = 5π/4, the antiderivative equals √2(5π+2)/4. At x = 3π/4, it equals √2(6−3π)/4. Their difference is √2[(5π+2)−(6−3π)]/4 = √2(8π−4)/4 = 2√2π − √2.

GPT-5-Codex.feedback: Relied on Attempt 3; confirmed the integration by parts step and endpoint evaluations, no corrections needed.

steps.title: Set up the cross-sectional area and volume integral
steps.content: Slices perpendicular to the x-axis are squares with side length s(x) = √[(1−2x)cos x]. On [3π/4, 5π/4], both (1−2x) and cos x are negative, so (1−2x)cos x ≥ 0 and s(x) is real. The area is A(x) = s(x)^2 = (1−2x)cos x. Volume V = ∫_{3π/4}^{5π/4} (1−2x)cos x dx.

steps.title: Find an antiderivative
steps.content: ∫(1−2x)cos x dx = ∫cos x dx − 2∫x cos x dx. With ∫x cos x dx = x sin x + cos x, an antiderivative is F(x) = sin x − 2x sin x − 2 cos x.

GPT-5.feedback: All three attempts used the correct setup V=∫[(1−2x)cos x] dx and correct integration by parts. Attempt 3 was the most complete, explicitly noting (1−2x) and cos x are negative on the interval so the area is (1−2x)cos x without absolute values. I followed that approach and streamlined the evaluation; no substantive corrections were needed.

steps.title: Identify the solid and volume formula
steps.content: The region bounded by y = √[(1-2x) cos x], the x-axis, and x = 3π/4 to x = 5π/4 is the base. Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are squares with side length equal to the height of the region at each x, which is y = √[(1-2x) cos x]. The area of each square is [y]^2 = (1-2x) cos x. Thus, the volume is V = ∫_{3π/4}^{5π/4} (1-2x) cos x dx.

steps.title: Compute the integral using integration by parts
steps.content: Let u = 1 - 2x, dv = cos x dx. Then du = -2 dx, v = sin x. ∫ u dv = uv - ∫ v du = (1-2x) sin x - ∫ sin x (-2) dx = (1-2x) sin x + 2 ∫ sin x dx = (1-2x) sin x - 2 cos x.

steps.title: Match to options
steps.content: The volume 2√2 π - √2 corresponds to option ③.

Grok 4 Fast.feedback: All previous attempts misinterpreted the function (wrong expressions and domains) and the solid setup (e.g., rotation instead of square cross-sections). Corrected by recognizing [y]^2 = (1-2x) cos x directly and computing the integral properly.

steps.title: Understand the problem
steps.content: We have a solid whose base is the region bounded by y = √((1-2x)cos x), the x-axis, and the vertical lines x = 3π/4 and x = 5π/4. Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are squares. We need to find the volume.

steps.title: Verify the function is well-defined
steps.content:
For y = √((1-2x)cos x) to be real, we need (1-2x)cos x ≥ 0. In the interval [3π/4, 5π/4]:
- 1-2x: At x = 3π/4 ≈ 2.36, we get 1-2(3π/4) = 1-3π/2 < 0. So (1-2x) < 0 throughout.
- cos x: In [3π/4, 5π/4], cos x ≤ 0 (second and third quadrants).
Since both factors are negative, their product is positive, so the square root is well-defined.

steps.title: Set up the volume integral
steps.content:
For a solid with square cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis, if the side length of each square is y, then the area is y². Here y = √((1-2x)cos x), so the cross-sectional area is A(x) = (1-2x)cos x.

Volume V = ∫[3π/4 to 5π/4] (1-2x)cos x dx

steps.title: Compute the antiderivative using integration by parts
steps.content:
Let u = 1-2x and dv = cos x dx
Then du = -2 dx and v = sin x

∫(1-2x)cos x dx = (1-2x)sin x - ∫sin x·(-2)dx
= (1-2x)sin x + 2∫sin x dx
= (1-2x)sin x - 2cos x + C

So F(x) = (1-2x)sin x - 2cos x

steps.title: Evaluate at the upper limit x = 5π/4
Evaluate at the lower limit x = 3π/4
Match with answer choices
steps.content: V = 2√2π - √2 matches option ③

self_aggregation.rationale: All four model solutions arrived at the same answer using consistent methods. The key steps are: (1) recognizing that the cross-sectional area is y² = (1-2x)cos x, (2) correctly applying integration by parts to get F(x) = (1-2x)sin x - 2cos x, and (3) carefully evaluating the definite integral. All models verified that the function is well-defined on the given interval. The calculations are straightforward and all solutions agree on 2√2π - √2.

steps.title: Understand the problem setup
steps.content: We have a curve y = √((1-2x)cosx) for 3π/4 ≤ x ≤ 5π/4. A solid has its base bounded by this curve, the x-axis, and lines x = 3π/4 and x = 5π/4. Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are squares with side length equal to y.

steps.title: Set up the volume integral
steps.content: For a solid with square cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis, the area of each cross-section is A(x) = y² = (1-2x)cosx. The volume is V = ∫[3π/4 to 5π/4] (1-2x)cosx dx.

steps.title: Verify the integrand is non-negative
steps.content: For x ∈ [3π/4, 5π/4]: (1-2x) is negative since 1-2(3π/4) = 1-3π/2 < 0. Also cosx is negative in this interval (cos(3π/4) = -√2/2, cos(5π/4) = -√2/2). So (1-2x)cosx = (negative)(negative) = positive, confirming the integrand represents a valid area.

steps.title: Split and evaluate the integral
steps.content:
V = ∫[3π/4 to 5π/4] cosx dx - 2∫[3π/4 to 5π/4] x·cosx dx.

First integral: ∫[3π/4 to 5π/4] cosx dx = [sinx] from 3π/4 to 5π/4 = sin(5π/4) - sin(3π/4) = -√2/2 - √2/2 = -√2.

Second integral uses integration by parts: ∫x·cosx dx = x·sinx - ∫sinx dx = x·sinx + cosx.

steps.title: Calculate the final volume
steps.content:
V = -√2 - 2(-√2π) = -√2 + 2√2π = 2√2π - √2.

This matches option ③.

Claude Opus 4.5.feedback: My solution agrees with GPT-5-Codex and GPT-5, all arriving at 2√2π - √2 (option ③). Grok 4 Fast appears to have misread the problem entirely, incorrectly interpreting it as a rotation problem and using wrong bounds. My approach correctly identifies the cross-sectional area as y² = (1-2x)cosx and properly evaluates the integral using integration by parts. The calculations are verified to be correct.

steps.title: Set up volume integral
steps.content: Square cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis have area A(x) = [√((1 − 2x) cos x)]² = (1 − 2x) cos x, so V = ∫_{3π/4}^{5π/4} (1 − 2x) cos x dx.

steps.title: Integrate the area function
steps.content: Antiderivative of (1 − 2x) cos x is F(x) = sin x − 2x sin x − 2 cos x.

GPT-5-Codex.feedback: My approach matches Claude Opus 4.5 and GPT-5, both of which computed V = 2√2π − √2. Grok 4 Fast solved a different problem setup. No changes were needed.

steps.title: Set up cross-sectional area
steps.content: Squares perpendicular to the x-axis have side s(x) = y = √((1−2x)cos x). Hence A(x) = s(x)^2 = (1−2x)cos x on [3π/4, 5π/4].

steps.title: Antiderivative
steps.content: ∫(1−2x)cos x dx = sin x − 2∫x cos x dx; with ∫x cos x dx = x sin x + cos x, we get F(x) = (1−2x)sin x − 2 cos x.

GPT-5.feedback: My setup and computation match Claude and GPT-5: use A(x) = y^2 = (1−2x)cos x and evaluate the definite integral to 2√2π − √2. Grok misread the problem as a volume of revolution and changed the function/interval, leading to an incorrect result. No changes needed.

steps.title: Understand the problem setup
steps.content: The solid is bounded by the curve y = √((1-2x) cos x) for 3π/4 ≤ x ≤ 5π/4, the x-axis, and the lines x=3π/4, x=5π/4. Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are squares with side length y(x), so cross-sectional area A(x) = [y(x)]² = (1-2x) cos x. The volume is V = ∫_{3π/4}^{5π/4} (1-2x) cos x dx.

steps.title: Compute the antiderivative
steps.content: ∫ (1-2x) cos x dx = ∫ cos x dx - 2 ∫ x cos x dx. The first integral is sin x. For the second, integration by parts: u=x, dv=cos x dx, du=dx, v=sin x, so ∫ x cos x dx = x sin x - ∫ sin x dx = x sin x + cos x. Thus, antiderivative F(x) = sin x - 2(x sin x + cos x) = sin x - 2x sin x - 2 cos x.

steps.title: Match to options
steps.content: The volume 2√2 π - √2 matches option ③.

steps.title: Understanding the Problem
steps.content: We have a curve y = √((1-2x)cos x) on the interval [3π/4, 5π/4]. The region bounded by this curve, the x-axis, and the vertical lines x = 3π/4 and x = 5π/4 forms the base of a solid. Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are squares with side length equal to y(x).

steps.title: Verify the integrand is non-negative
steps.content:
For x ∈ [3π/4, 5π/4]:
- (1-2x): At x = 3π/4, we get 1 - 3π/2 ≈ 1 - 4.71 < 0. So (1-2x) is negative throughout.
- cos x: At x = 3π/4, cos(3π/4) = -√2/2 < 0. At x = 5π/4, cos(5π/4) = -√2/2 < 0. So cos x is negative throughout.
- Therefore (1-2x)cos x = (negative)(negative) = positive, confirming y is real and the area is valid.

steps.title: Set up the volume integral
steps.content:
Since cross-sections are squares with side y(x), the cross-sectional area is A(x) = y² = (1-2x)cos x.

Volume V = ∫_{3π/4}^{5π/4} (1-2x)cos x dx

steps.title: Split the integral
steps.content:
V = ∫_{3π/4}^{5π/4} cos x dx - 2∫_{3π/4}^{5π/4} x cos x dx

Let I₁ = ∫_{3π/4}^{5π/4} cos x dx
Let I₂ = ∫_{3π/4}^{5π/4} x cos x dx

So V = I₁ - 2I₂

steps.title: Evaluate I₂ using integration by parts

cross_aggregation.rationale: All four model solutions arrived at the same answer through consistent methods. The integral setup is correct (square cross-sections with area y²), and the integration by parts for ∫x cos x dx is standard. The evaluation at the bounds was verified and all solutions agree on V = 2√2π - √2, which matches option ③.
